prove.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to show that something is true by providing facts, information etc
prove.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: You’re wrong, and I can prove it.
To prove his point  (=show that he was right), he mentioned several other experiments which had produced similar results.
He claims the police destroyed records that could prove the officer’s guilt.
They say I’m too old, but I’m going to prove them all wrong.
Tests have proved that the system works.
I knew he had done it, but there was no way I could prove it to Eddie.
prove.translation[0].definitions[0].note: I will prove to you that I’m right
I will prove you that I’m right
prove.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if someone or something proves difficult, helpful, a problem etc, they are difficult, helpful, a problem etc
prove.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The recent revelations may prove embarrassing to the president.
The design proved to be a success.
prove.translation[0].definitions[1].note: Prove is a linking verb in this meaning This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
He has proved a loyal friend
The task proved to be difficult
He has proved to be a loyal friend
prove.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if dough (=unbaked bread mixture) proves, it rises and becomes light because of the yeast in it
prove.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to show that a will has been made in the correct way
prove.translation[0].note_box[0].section: There was no way she could prove her innocence.
These pictures do not prove the existence of water on Mars.
No evidence emerged to prove either theory.
The state had failed to prove its case.
To prove her point, Dr Hurdal showed her audience a scan of a patient’s brain.
See if you can prove me wrong.
The law states that you are innocent until proved guilty.
